page.title: 02CARISBROOKE CASTLE
page.content: Carisbrooke Castle is a Norman motte and bailey castle with Elizabethan outer defences. It used to be the residence of the Lord. and later the Governor, of the Isle of Wight. Parts of the castle are ruined now, but the keep and most of the curtain wall are standing, and some of the buildings inside it are still used. One range of buildings houses a museum of Isle of Wight history; another is divided into flats - one for the Head Custodian, and one for the Head of the Maintenance Dept; and the chapel in the courtyard is still used occasionally for services. The castle is in the care of English Heritage, and it is one of the Island's main tourist attractions. About 130,000 people visit it every year.
